content: every once in a while you got to just give in and build yourself a gimmicky
prop just because it's cool
hey guys welcome back to blackmagic
craft it has been quite some time since i've done a video or a project
where i did anything to add to my basic generic dungeon tile
system these tiles are essentially the
foundation of this entire channel and kind of where it all started last
week when i was making my lava tiles i experimented with a third option using
some real leds and i didn't like
the attempt i thought it was really silly and kind of dumb
and i scrapped it but it got me thinking about actually using led lights
in tiles in a way that wasn't stupid and was actually effective
in general i think adding lights to tiles is a pointless endeavor that
doesn't really add too much to the gaming experience and
certainly isn't worth it relative to the effort however
once in a while you just gotta do it because because you can and because it's
cool and i came up with this glowing
magic arcane runes i made some missteps along the way
of which i will gladly share with you but in the end i came up with something
pretty excited about the idea was to have these work with my basic 3x3 tile
so i started with a 3x3 square of half inch
xps foam for the lights i'm using one of these string lights with a very slim
battery holder that you can pick up in bulk for pretty cheap on amazon i'll
throw a link in the description if you want to grab
some to hold the lights i broke the tile down into
three layers the first layer was cut at a thickness that was just slightly
thicker than the battery pack then a very thin layer was sliced for the top
on the bottom layer i cut out the shape of the battery pack making sure to keep
it nice and tight the length of this cut was made a little bit long to
accommodate the toggle switch and where the wire comes out for the
middle layer this will act as an empty space to hold the leds
i cut out a square that would serve as a sort of frame
then i used some hot glue to secure the battery pack and the middle layer in
place it's really important on the battery pack to leave the side with the
screws accessible this is so you can change the
batteries in the future because you will inevitably end up leaving this thing
turned on overnight and the batteries will die the
tricky part with these led wires is getting them laid out evenly and
nicely i was tempted to just leave them as a coil but
that would be too thick to fit inside the tile and it would concentrate all
the light right in the middle which i didn't want
so using low temperature hot glue and a fair bit of patience i
carefully and slowly spread the led wire through the whole area the trick to this
was using a minimal amount of hot glue just as
little as possible so that it cooled quickly
and making use of an object or a wet finger to hold it in place while the
glue cooled this was finicky it was annoying
but it was super important to get right for this project
with the lights in place it was time to think about
filling in that void see i didn't want it to be hollow
the top layer of foam is really thin so i wanted something that would fill the
area and create a solid surface for it to sit
on but while remaining translucent the hope is that this would
also diffuse the light a little bit i first grab some translucent acrylic
latex caulking it applies white and dries clear but
i got worried that it wouldn't dry clear enough and i scrapped that idea and
moved instead to gloss gel this stuff also applies white and
dries clear but for some reason i trusted it more on a thick application
for the first layer i mixed in some green ink that was
a similar color to the leds in the hopes of creating a translucent green
gel to encapsulate the light i only applied a thin layer of this tinted gel
and filled the rest with stuff right out of the pot i didn't want to diffuse the
light too much and make it too dim as i've made that mistake in the past
while that cures i'd like to take a minute to tell you about the sponsor of

is what has made me become really comfortable using this technology
what's great about archvillains monthly service is that they also offer another

and meant to be used with the models so this is ideal for people that are
signing up to get models for their rpg games
if you're looking for slick sculpts and want rule supplements to use in your
game this is a great service for you i'll put
a link in the video description so you can jump over and get your hand
on their sweet models this month for yourself
and if you want to pick up some of their models from previous months i'll put a
link to where you can get those as well thanks archbillin for sponsoring this
video and for helping me descend into my own personal madness
while that cured i got to work cutting out the arcane symbol
in the top layer of foam it's probably worth drawing your design
on the foam first and then cutting it out but i
personally just really enjoy freehanding this sort of thing but do that at your
own risk the most important thing to keep in mind while
doing this is that you need to avoid accidentally cutting out areas you don't
mean to you have to be really mindful of how
lines intersect and interact and treat this kind of like a
stencil in order to not lose any pieces you really want to avoid cross cuts this
thin layer of foam with everything cut out is pretty delicate so a coat of mod
podge on all the sides and edges is really important now after letting it
sit to cure for 24 hours that gloss gel was not
turning clear the top layer head cured and was hard and dry
but underneath was still wet and still white it was simply
applied too thick i was concerned that this would happen when i applied it
but for some reason you know i was just being hopeful as i often am that it
would just work out but it didn't it probably would have turned
clear eventually like maybe in a couple weeks but i did
not want to wait that long so i peeled it all out leaving just that
thin original layer of tinted stuff to cure a little bit longer
and once that was fully dry which didn't take too long i moved to the material i
should have used right from the start five minute dollar
store epoxy this used to be my go-to for many things but i keep
forgetting to use it in favor of other stuff lately i don't know why
almost every time i end up regretting it the stuff is so dependable
and it cures in minutes so you know what's gonna happen
immediately if i were to make one of these again in the future i would just
do this right from the start maybe adding a few drops of ink mixed in just
to tint it to avoid getting any paint on the resin
i pre-painted the top layer this was also a lot easier and
faster as i could just over brush everything without any worry
this could be done in any stone painting method you'd like
you could go really crazy with it and make some sort of colorful magic stone
but personally i wanted it to sort of match my basic tiles
matching my old paint job was pretty easy as it just meant some simple gray
dry brushing followed by some black and brown
washes to attach the top layer i just used some basic pva glue but i spread it
out really thin and let it sit for a bit so it kind of tacked up before i put it
in place my resin was nice and flat so it was
easy to push the top layer really firm and securely down onto the tile i
decided to clad the edges of my tile with some construction paper
to make it more durable and hide the layer lines
this really isn't necessary as you don't actually see the sides when it's placed
alongside other tiles but i think it's a nice way to finish it
off the moment of truth is testing the lights
and thankfully despite my blunders with the gel the resin was a great fix and if
you were to go this route right from the start i think you'd have a really
successful build i thought about making the top layer
removable so you could swap out cymbals and you could certainly try that but
personally i prefer the durability of a piece that has itself all glued
together and would rather just make more as needed i really hope you enjoyed
this video and found something useful in it if you did give it a thumbs up and
share it with your friends or in your favorite hobby groups and drop me a
comment below all of those things really help these
videos gain traction on youtube if you want to grab a pack of
those string lights there will be a link in the video description but if you're

my essential equipment page on blackmagicraft.com there i've curated
a list explaining all the stuff that i use most
and shopping on that page helps fund the production of videos like this
i make these videos each and every week and i'm able to do so

of value out of these videos i make and want to help me keep making them the

i'd love to have you as the newest member of the blackmagic craft
fellowship that's it for this week guys thanks for watching cheers and happy
crafting
